bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert G. Love, August 12, 1952

div1.p: Hench stresses the importance of the final name for the Camp Lazear site. He also thinks it is important that the Army medical department and the State Department have representatives at the ceremony. Hench requests that Love contact Siler and Lawrence Reed to find out if they plan to attend the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert G. Love, August 12, 1952
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
August 12, 1952
General Albert E. Love
2709 Wisconsin Avenue N.W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Love:
div1.p:
Please see the enclosed memorandum and covering letter which I am sending to
the Surgeon General of the U.S. Army.

I am greatly concerned about the possibility that the Surgeon General may be
away and that some deputy may not realize the minor urgency of this matter.
I admit that in view of world events this matter is relatively unimportant.
On the other hand, if the Cubans do dedicate Camp Lazear in six or seven
weeks. I think you will agree with me that it is important that it be dedicated
with the right names. I think you will aggree it is important also that the
medical department of the Army, and perhaps also the State Department, have
representatives there.

Can you do me a real favor? Can you first get in touch with Colonel Siler
and General Reed, at least by telephone? (I am sending them each a copy
of my memorandum to the Surgeon General and my letter to you.) Could you
find out whether General Reed would be agreeable to going to Cuba for the
dedication under the proper circumstances? With this tentative information,
could you then call someone whom you know in the Surgeon General's Office and
make sure that somebody there is looking over my memorandum and enclosures?
Also, you might discretely inquire as to whether Generals Reed and Truby
might somehow be activated long enough to go to the dedication. I hope that
General and Mrs. Reed can make some arrangements to go if they wish to do so
but certainly he would not make any inquiries from the Surgeon General. That
must be handled by his friends; if possible by you on the scene and by me by
correspondence.

I think it is important for the Surgeon General and for someone in the State
Department representing Cuban affairs, to know what is going on but I hope that
no one will upset the apple cart. In view of Doctor Nogueira's letter, I think
we must allow him to act freely and not give him or other Cubans any indica-
tion of any pressure at this time. I might add that as for the concern ex-
pressed in my letters of July 7 and 26 to him, I can assure you that I was
not alone in this concern. Indeed resting on the assurances of Doctor Nogueira,
I was the last one to become concerned. Others who anticipated my concern
were Miss Agramonte, Miss Rojas (owner of the Finca San Jose), Doctor Carbonell,
Mrs. Smith (President of FIM in Cuba) and one or two others.

I shall be away for two weeks but whatever information you have please send to
my address at the Clinic. My secretary is completely informed about the matter
under discussion, has instructions as to what to do under various contingencies,
and will forward the letters air mail to me. In any event I shall be back the
first week in September.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Copy to Doctor Siler and Gen. Reed. & Gen. Truby
